irb_consent.title: Research Study Information
text: You are invited to participate in a research study about wildfire evacuation decision-making.
Your participation is voluntary. You may stop at any time without penalty.
Your responses will be kept confidential and used for research purposes only.
This study involves reviewing information and making decisions in a simulated wildfire scenario.

contact_screen.title: Contact Information (Optional)
text: If you are willing, you may provide contact information so we can follow up with you about this study.
Providing contact information is optional and not required to participate.

scenario_description.title: Scenario
text: You live in a single-family home in a suburban neighborhood with your partner and two children. The children
(10 and 13 years old) are currently at home with the family dog. Your partner is traveling and can't be reached.
Your household owns two cars. One car is with your partner, and the other is parked at home. The car at home has
approximately one-quarter of a tank of gas remaining. A public transportation bus stop is located within walking
There has never been a wildfire in your immediate area before, and you have not previously needed to evacuate due
to fire. Your home is not specially prepared or hardened for wildfire risk (for example, there is limited defensible
At the start of the scenario, daily activities are proceeding normally. You are responsible for decisions affecting
yourself, your children, and your pet during the unfolding situation.
Over the next several hours, conditions may worsen or improve.
You will be able to receive information from different sources.
At each stage, review the available information and decide what you would do to deal with the situation.

preparation_actions.label: Gather essentials
preparation_actions.description: Collect medications, IDs, chargers, keys, and a change of clothes.

preparation_actions.label: Prepare Children
preparation_actions.description: Collect documents, clothes, valuables and electronics.

preparation_actions.label: Check on your Neighbors
preparation_actions.description: Talk to neighbors and make sure they are aware of recent developments

preparation_actions.label: Prepare your car
preparation_actions.description: Fill up your car's tank with gas

preparation_actions.label: Find a place to evacuate to
preparation_actions.description: Call friends and relatives to find a place to stay if you evacuate

cautious_friend.-6: I heard about the fire, but it still sounds pretty far away.
cautious_friend.-5: It smells smoky here too. I'm watching the updates.
cautious_friend.-4: Some people nearby are packing, but I haven't decided yet.
cautious_friend.-3: Traffic is starting to look bad. If you go, sooner is probably better.
cautious_friend.-2: This is getting serious. I think leaving is the safer option.
cautious_friend.-1: You really should leave now if you haven't already.

skeptical_friend.-6: Fires happen every year. I wouldn't stress yet.
skeptical_friend.-5: Officials tend to overreact with these warnings.
skeptical_friend.-4: I'm staying put. The fire still seems far.
skeptical_friend.-3: Traffic is worse than the fire in my opinion.
skeptical_friend.-2: I'm still not convinced evacuation is necessary.
skeptical_friend.-1: If you're calm at home, staying might be fine.

alarmist_friend.-6: I don't like this at all. Fires spread fast.
alarmist_friend.-5: Smoke already worries me. I'd start getting ready.
alarmist_friend.-4: If you wait too long, roads will be packed.
alarmist_friend.-3: I would leave now if you can.
alarmist_friend.-2: This is dangerous. You should be evacuating.
alarmist_friend.-1: Please tell me you're already on your way out.
